Suozzi, a Representative in Congress from the State of New York................................... 59 </option> <Doc-title>U.S. POLICY TOWARD AFGHANISTAN</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 10:00 a.m., in room 2172 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman Royce">This hearing on U.S. policy toward Afghanistan will come to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">Afghanistan has been at war since 1979. The human suffering has been horrendous. Real threats to U.S. national security have followed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">As a result, the U.S. has had no choice but to engage in Afghanistan. First, we helped counter the brutal Soviet invasion and then we helped dislodge the Taliban and combat al- Qaeda after the September 11 attacks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">Afghanistan has been called ``America's longest war.'' Thousands of Americans have lost their lives. We have spent hundreds of billions of dollars.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">This investment aims to achieve a stable Afghanistan that does not harbor international terrorists. Should the Afghan Government fail, the vacuum surely would be filled.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">ISIS and the ayatollah would be among those who would benefit. So today we will ask: Where should we go from here?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">We currently have 14,000 U.S. troops in Afghanistan. This is dramatically down from a high of 100,000 in 2011. Their current focus is training Afghan security forces and counterterrorism, and there has been some success.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">Fortunately, many allies are still with us. But Afghans need the ability and also the will to fight for their own country.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">Last week, there was a brief cease fire and renewed Afghan Government outreach to the Taliban, which the administration endorsed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">Yet, the Taliban continues the fight and has rejected all offers to enter into negotiations with the internationally recognized and backed Afghan Government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">This conflict does not need a sustainable political resolution of some sort that is going to fall apart. What it needs is a well-thought through sustainable situation that will hold for the people of Afghanistan and that leads to a credible competent Afghan Government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">And the administration moved these things in the right direction by scrapping restrictive rules of engagement that had hamstrung U.S. forces. It dropped a politically-driven time line for our engagement established by the previous administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">It's putting more pressure on Pakistan, which aids and abets the Taliban and other jihadist groups, and Taliban finances are being targeted.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">These are good steps, but it's unclear if they will change the fundamentals that have frustrated an acceptable resolution for so long.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce">After all these years, what do we really know about the Taliban? How fragmented is it? Can it ever be brought into a durable political settlement?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Royce">Would Pakistan, or Russia and Iran, both increasingly engaged with the Taliban, sabotage any settlement?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Royce">We should be proud of our many contributions to development in Afghanistan, including dramatically expanding education and the cause of women, despite rampant corruption.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Royce">I've met with some of these women. The girls can now go to schools. That was prohibited, of course, under the Taliban. I've talked to teachers who've had the soles of their feet lashed when they were caught teaching girls.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Royce">The stories of these girls are incredibly inspiring. The stories of women who are now part of the government in Afghanistan are inspiring.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Royce">But, frankly, in other ways, we've been treading water. While leaving today would do more harm than good, our substantial military and development commitment to Afghanistan cannot be open-ended.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Royce">We need to see more progress. And with that, if we have-- our ranking member is not with us yet but he'll make his statement, Ambassador Wells, after your opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Royce">So this morning, I am pleased to welcome Alice Wells, Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs to the committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman Royce">Ambassador Alice G. Wells has been serving as the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs since June 2017.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman Royce">She is a career Foreign Service officer and she has previously served as the United States Ambassador to the Kingdom of Jordan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Chairman Royce">She has held numerous positions within the Department of State and has extensive experience in South and Central Asia, and we very much appreciate her being with us today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Chairman Royce">Without objection, the witness' full prepared statement is going to be made part of the record. Members are going to have 5 calendar days to submit any statements or questions or extraneous material for the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Chairman Royce">And I'll ask Ambassador Wells if she would summarize her remarks and then afterwards we will go to questions.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS, PRINCIPAL DEPUTY</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Thank you. ASSISTANT SECRETARY, BUREAU OF SOUTH AND CENTRAL ASIAN AFFAIRS,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Ambassador Wells. Chairman Royce and Ranking Member Engel, thank you for inviting me to appear today to discuss the administration's strategy in Afghanistan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">This is a timely hearing. Just last week, a cease fire--the first in 17 years--brought peace to Afghanistan during the period of Eid and, like many Americans, I was struck by the images of Afghan soldiers and Taliban praying together, side by side.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">If Afghan troops and Taliban foot soldiers can pray together, then the Afghan people have every reason to believe that their leaders can come together and negotiate an end to this war.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Helping to jumpstart an Afghan peace process is among Secretary Pompeo's highest priorities and has been my primary focus since assuming responsibility for this account 1 year ago.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">The President's South Asia strategy, announced last August, is making a difference. Its conditions-based approach has signaled to the Taliban that they cannot win on the battlefield, and has provided President Ghani with renewed confidence to pursue a negotiated political settlement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">His February 2018 invitation to the Taliban to enter into a peace process without preconditions as unprecedented. Equally unprecedented was President Ghani's announcement of the temporary cease fire for the weeks surrounding the Eid holidays.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">The national outpouring of relief and joy last weekend was unlike anything Afghanistan has seen. Taliban fighters wandered the streets of the cities. They took selfies with Afghan soldiers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">The sampled Eid treats with Afghan citizens and they worshiped alongside those they had been exchanging fire with just a few days earlier.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">For many Afghans, Taliban and pro-government alike, it was an exhilarating first taste of what peace might look like.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">The United States has made clear that we are prepared to support, facilitate, and participate in direct negotiations between the Afghan Government and the Taliban.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">We will support all Afghan stakeholders as they work to reach a mutually agreeable negotiated settlement that ends the conflict and ensures Afghanistan is never again used as a safe haven for terrorist groups.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Our desired outcomes for any peace process are clear and have not changed. The Taliban must renounce violence, break ties with al-Qaeda, and accept the Afghan constitution, including its protections for women and minorities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Although the Taliban and ISIS Khorasan remain potent enemies, the South Asia strategy is having an impact on the battlefield. With tactical level support from U.S. military advisors, the Afghan security forces have slowed the Taliban's momentum.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Improved air support, a generational shift in leadership, and a doubling of the size of special forces are creating conditions for a political process to achieve a lasting peace.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Alongside our military campaign we are working with our partners, especially in the Gulf, to help strangle the Taliban's illicit revenue from foreign sources and narcotics trafficking.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">We are supporting the Afghan Government's outreach to the global Muslim community to delegitimize the religious underpinnings of the Taliban's violent campaign and we are also calling on Afghanistan's neighbors, especially Pakistan, to take additional steps in support of peace.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">Despite some positive indicators, we have not yet seen Pakistan take the sustained or the decisive steps that we believe it should pursue, including arresting or expelling Taliban elements who will not come to the negotiating table.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">We are also encouraging the Afghan Government reforms in a bid to further sap the insurgency of support. Upcoming Afghan elections for Parliament in October and for President in early 2019 must be timely, transparent, and credible.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">We are providing targeted assistance to Afghan electoral institutions to assist with voter registration and reduce electoral fraud. More than 6 million Afghans have registered to vote and more than 5,000 candidates will be standing for public office.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">President Ghani is an economic reformer, but Afghanistan still ranks near the bottom in Transparency International's rankings. There has been some institutional progress, including the establishment of an anti-corruption justice center.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">But progress has been slow. However, there have been bright spots as well. Over the last year, the Afghan Government has improved its fiscal performance and is a funding a greater share of its budget.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">The U.S. share of pledged donor support has dropped from about 50 percent in 2012 to 25 percent today. The Afghan people who face the deadly toll of this war every day understand the need for peace and so too do the thousands of U.S. personnel working to implement the administration's strategy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">As I noted earlier, the key questions remains: Will the Taliban join the peace process and make the compromises necessary to end the war?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="THE HONORABLE ALICE G. WELLS">We are prepared to test this proposition.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Ambassador Wells follows:][GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Ambassador Wells ">Mr. Chairman, Mr. Ranking Member, thank you for the opportunity to appear before your committee. Congress' support is crucial to our strategic progress and I look forward to addressing your questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Ambassador Wells ">[GRAPHICS NOT AVAILABLE IN TIFF FORMAT]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Ambassador Wells "> ---------- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Ambassador Well.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce"> We now go to Mr. Eliot Engel of New York, the ranking member of the committee. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you for calling this hearing, and Ambassador, thank you for your time and for your service.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Engel">Our policy, obviously, toward Afghanistan is critical. Fifteen thousand American troops remain on the ground there fighting America's longest war and we provide billions in assistance every year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Engel">In the 17 years since Americans first deployed to Afghanistan after September 11th, our troops and those of our allies have performed heroically. There has been significant progress on the counterterrorism front against al-Qaeda.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Engel">Once estimated as many as 5,000, the number of al-Qaeda fighters in Afghanistan is now thought to be in the low hundreds. Unfortunately, those gains against al-Qaeda aren't comparable to the fight against the Taliban, which most experts consider a stalemate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Engel">The Trump administration announced its approach to deal with the stalemate nearly a year ago in what it termed a new strategy for Afghanistan and South Asia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Engel">It is meant to be a so-called conditions-based approach that emphasizes fighting to win, downplays nation building, includes a stronger line against Pakistan, and a larger role for India, eliminates time tables, expands targeting authorities for U.S. forces and, notably, commits to sending additional troops.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Engel">In sum, the administration seems to be planning to escalate the war in order to break the stalemate, forcing the Taliban to the negotiating table.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Engel">But what happens if that stalemate is not broken? In its April 2018 report, the U.S. special inspector general for Afghanistan reconstruction--what we call SIGAR--found that the share of districts in Afghanistan under government control or influence is 56 percent.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Engel">Unfortunately, that ties the lowest level ever recorded by SIGAR. So we need to be honest. Even with the best military in the world it's impossible to kill every member of the Taliban.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Engel">Despite the President's talk, even members of the administration acknowledge that the war in Afghanistan will not be won on the battlefield. The President needs a strategy based on the facts as they are, not as he wishes them to be.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Engel">So I thank all of the countries which have committed troops to the fight in Afghanistan for so many years. But I worry with attacks on NATO and our allies coming from the President we are undermining the very alliance which binds the coalition fighting for the future of Afghanistan and our security.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Engel">So rather than putting more Americans in harm's way, the administration should focus its resources on achieving a political resolution to the conflict. It's a tough pill to swallow, no doubt about it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Engel">Many brave Americans have perished at the hands of Taliban fighters. The Taliban's continued existence is a fact we need to deal with and the old adage remains true--you don't make peace with your friends.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Engel">Taliban refuses to talk directly with the Afghan Government. They view it as illegitimate. That's, obviously, made progress on reconciliation impossible.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Engel">However, the Taliban has maintained an interest in talking with the United States, even after the President told the U.N. Security Council this past January that the U.S. wasn't prepared to talk right now.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Engel">That's a mistake. If American interests are best served by negotiating directly with the Taliban, then we should stop kicking the can down the road.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Engel">The Taliban claim that they will completely separate themselves from international terrorism and respect the rights of women and minorities--it's time to see if they are serious.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Engel">Recent developments may give us an opening--the recent Afghan Government cease fire, the Taliban separate but reciprocal cease fire, a potential convergence of interests against the growing threat of the ISIS offshoot in Afghanistan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Engel">So far, we have squandered the opportunity. We have heard nothing about how we plan to seize on the cease fire, and that's no real surprise because, as I have been finding for many, many months now, the administration doesn't prioritize diplomacy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Engel">The State Department Office of the Inspector General found that the Bureau of South and Central Asian Affairs ``lost both staff and expertise'' as a result of the reckless hollowing out of the State Department.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Engel">Among those cuts were the experts on peace talks with the Taliban and reconciliation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Engel">So, Ambassador Wells, now that the hiring freeze is over we will be interested in hearing how the administration plans to reconstitute this expertise. We cannot miss the next diplomatic opportunity because we don't have diplomats up to the job.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel">And diplomacy is going to be at the center of solving this challenge. After many years of war, it's crystal clear that there is no military solution to end the fighting in Afghanistan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">But that doesn't foreclose a path to peace that advances American security interests. Now is the time to make peace and security our number-one goal and to implement a strategy in Afghanistan that will help us achieve it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">We owe this to the women and men who serve our country in uniform, to those who gave the ultimate sacrifice fighting this war, and to those who perished on September 11, 2001, in my home city of New York.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">So I look forward to your testimony. I know you've started and we are very happy to have you here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel"> I thank you again, Mr. Chairman, and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Mr. Engel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Chairman Royce">So, Ambassador Wells, I think the key question here in terms of the willingness of factions in the Taliban or the overall organization to reach some kind of settlement goes to their intentions, and there have been cease fires. But yesterday there were 30 Afghans killed by Taliban soldiers when, on the Taliban side, they lifted that cease fire.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Chairman Royce">Let me ask you, in your judgment is the Taliban, at the end of the day, interested in a political settlement? What do circumstances tell you and how would we get there?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Chairman Royce">We saw President Ghani offer a series of moves, of prisoners releases, medical aid for wounded soldiers, this latest cease fire, and fraternization that presumably might bring down the tensions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Chairman Royce">And yet, here was the attack yesterday. Give me your view on this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Chairman Royce">Ambassador Wells. The Taliban have long said that they do support a political--or negotiations but only with the United States, not with the sovereign Government of Afghanistan, and I think what we learned from this cease fire that was very interesting was just how much the foot soldiers and the commanders inside of Afghanistan do desire peace, and the celebration of the Eid was spontaneous and it was countrywide.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Chairman Royce">And so I think where we are right now is the Taliban leadership, many of whom enjoy sanctuary outside of the country and don't feel the pressures of day-to-day war, have not yet been convinced to come to the negotiating table, despite what has been an extremely forward-leaning offer of peace put forward by President Ghani in February.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Chairman Royce">That peace offer, which was unconditional without any preconditions attached to it and included the offer of considering constitutional amendments to ensure that the Taliban's views were better reflected in the institutions and structure of the Government of Afghanistan, that offer has been endorsed by the international community.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Chairman Royce"> And so our strategy right now I think has to be focused on increasing the pressure that the Taliban feel to take up that offer of negotiation. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Chairman Royce">And one of the difficulties in all of this, in getting an organization--a terrorist organization like that to the table is the financing for that organization that makes cash ready at hand every time they are moving narcotics.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Chairman Royce">I guess one of the great frustrations is for the last 15 years the U.S. Government has spent $8 billion focused on trying to shut down that and today it is still the biggest cash crop in Afghanistan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Chairman Royce">What, in theory, could be done to try to diminish that narcotics trade and all the illegality that that drives as well as the support for the Taliban from a financial standpoint?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Chairman Royce">Ambassador Wells. I agree. The narcotics, we assess, account for about 60 percent of the Taliban budget but, more than that, they fuel a criminal network and eat away at the institutions of state through the corruption that they also cause.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Chairman Royce">What we have done, partly, it's a problem of security. Eighty-five percent of opium is grown in areas that are controlled or contested by the Taliban.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Chairman Royce">So a key element in combating the Taliban finances is continuing to improve on the battlefield, which we are starting to see a decline in the Taliban's momentum as a result of the South Asia strategy and the new authorities and the new approach that has been adopted underneath that strategy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Chairman Royce">But we are also building the institutional capacity of the Afghan Government to prosecute and go after narco criminals and that has been through working with the ministry of counter narcotics, building special investigative units and national investigation units, working with President Ghani in support of a national drug action plan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Chairman Royce">And there have been some successes.
